main_text: I worked at Payless ShoeSource full-time for more than a year
pros: Worked at the EDC for over a year, and escaped this fiasco post-bankruptcy(the second one). * If you get an assignment there as a temp you will actually, literally get away with doing next to nothing for $13.50 an hour. *You won't have to work 40 hours some weeks, sometimes not even 20. On the flip side, when they need to catch up from those grace periods, you will work 60 to even 70 hours a week. Both can be interpreted as good if you have no self-value. *You do start at 13.50 an hour(13.00 for first shift). I have no clue how they can afford to shell this out to the hundreds that worked/have worked there. *They're closing now, so if you're hired on you get incentive for sticking around until the end, if your sanity will last that long. *Your breaks are paid, which is indeed nice if you ignore the fact there is only 2 of them lasting 20 minutes. *The survivors of this apocalypse of a company are absolutely terrific to work with. I'd say about half are absolutely out of cares to give. The other half rant all day while they do their job at 130%. But each have become a wonderful friend to me. *There are safety and wellness committee meetings you can go to for information and advice. *The benefits were not bad at all. You do not have the time to utilize them.
cons: This list that I am about to write could never include all of the issues that I have for this establishment. It is an absolute plethora. I almost don't even want to start, because it will never be enough. *You will never move up. You will never be recognized for your work. If you take time to clean, organize, or generally assist the workfloor whatsoever, even timely and reasonably, you are penalized. If you can't write it as "off-standard" without a coach's permission, your numbers take a hit, you get paid less. This leads to layers, layers, and layers of dust, dirt, grime, probably dried tears as well. *I have only met 5 people in my YEAR of employment who were able to stay for more than 3 months in my own department. *Speaking of departments, don't get used to your own. Once you bust your rear end to finish your own department, you are sent to another one to help the people who couldn't do the same(probably temps((see pro #1))). This makes everyone pace themselves to the degree where we ride the minimum until 10 to 12 hours was over. *You get notified of 1 or 2 hours overtime about 3 hours prior. *They have people sorted into keys to be called in for overtime, one for every day of every shift. They do this really cool thing where they make some keys work A LOT more than others :) if you're key 1 or 2 you're good though. *While it is to monitor your productivity and progress, you are perpetually monitored. Sure, it's through security cameras, RF scan logs, and your own timesheet, but it's also through your team lead, as he likes to watch everyone from the catwalk on busy days for quite a bit of time. *As I have referenced, your productivity is measured and you are paid incentive based on said number. They have "engineered" standards set in place. These "engineered" standards do not measure all that you encounter in a job(which is acknowledged daily by coaches and team leads), so you are essentially pinned against an arbitrary value for a living. * Having a grand total of 40 minutes to yourself for 10 hours a day is stressful. Luckily, there are numerous system failures, system downtime, and general breaches of network integrity to give you a little break from the hustle and bustle of productivity.

She didn't follow company standards that I had been following for over the 3.5 years I was there. She was not a team player. It just really shows how much can change when you have a bad manager. She couldn't hire anyone and failed to do most of her managerial duties. Also Payless was super crazy with making sure we went through the "customer journey" with every person who walked through. main_text: I worked at Payless ShoeSource full-time for more than 5 years
pros: I learned a lot about the company while working there. I worked there for 5 years before quitting to stay home with the kids. While there, i learned about the store layout, inventory, receiving and verifying shipments, rack representation, deposits, opening and closing procedures, interview process, training, conference calls, coaching, Crm, UPT/DPT, conversion, etc. I had learned almost everything the manager had known.
cons: Hours in winter, they are open until 9pm when NO ONE is outside. They complain about payroll, but corporate doesn't realize you paid us 2 hours of just cleaning, rack repping, and running shipment. No growth within company from associate. At least, not under my manager, or DM. Too much responsibility for a shoe company to give its new employees. If you want your stores to look neat, tidy and full then you need to spend the money on payroll. Have the right amount of staffing in order to do the jobs required, instead of making 1 person do the task of 3+. "You have to spend money to make money". There should always be a manager on spot, there was hardly ever a manager in when i was closing. I had to step up and handle the customers complaints or give them corporates number. Conversion is a waste of time and stress. If my numbers are sales are high, then people are buying. You have no idea how many of the same people walk in and out in 20 minutes. Conversion is stupid. Get rid of it. Also, they need mens shoes. If your not going to offer a great variety of mens, then make it a store for women. It's pathetic. The men's shoes are more expensive (because it's a rarity) so we would be making more money on them If they offered more styles. Same with boys.

main_text: I have been working at Payless ShoeSource full-time

cons: The expectations that corporate has for part-time employees are completely ridiculous. Tracking all sorts of KPIs (conversion, sales, units per transaction, customer relationship management) is unrealistic for people who are only at the store for 10-15 hours a week. District managers for my location were hired externally and did not know the first thing about what day-to-day operations at the store level were like. Incredibly cold and rude during store visits. -There is also no clear review structure or any kind of incentives to back up goals which leads to low motivation and very high turnover. I was a key holder and was assigned tasks far beyond my job description (I basically did everything an assistant manager does without the benefits), yet it took a state law that was passed to increase minimum wage for me to get any kind of raise in nearly two years. We went through at least ten part timers and two store managers within my time there and there were numerous occasions where hours got cut due to lack of payroll. -Inventory management was atrocious; we were either way overstocked or severely understocked and never with items that were in demand from our customers. I went into a store recently and saw shoes on clearance that were there when I first started in 2015. I am not surprised that the company had to file for bankruptcy protection and closed hundreds of stores; they got far too expansion-happy and don't care about actually retaining current stores/employees.

review_title: Good For Extra Pay, But Don't Expect Much!
main_text: I worked at Payless ShoeSource part-time for more than a year
pros: Employee discount and lots of teamwork. Most of my coworkers were awesome. It's good for a first job, or for a job if you just need a little extra income. If you're decent at your job, you'll be made a keyholder, which looks great on resumes. You get to do pretty much everything in the store, so you learn a lot about how to run a store and you get some pretty good skills from it.
cons: No flexibility. Management doesn't care. Minimum wage with no raises unless you happen to be a favorite of the district or regional manager. You're expected to go above and beyond what is expected of you, with no compensation for it. The goals were always way too high. My manager didn't care that I was in college; she would schedule me for hours that I couldn't work. Customers can be very rude and nasty. I got cussed out a handful of times by customers.

main_text: I worked at Payless ShoeSource part-time for more than a year

Its really not complicated, since its basically just shoe boxes its not hard to stock and keep the store clean. When it comes to shipment and pricing its a bit of hard work sometimes but usually easy. You can get good deals on shoes because of the discount, and learning which sales are actually the best deals.
cons: If you live in a small town you are only going to have about 3 other coworkers, Which means if you need a certain day off, get sick, or aren't pulling your weight its going to affect everyone else. Theft will be impossible to "prevent" because you will be working alone a lot and without giving to much away, there aren't many other security measures being used. People will walk out wearing new shoes so you have to watch them. You will get blamed for pilferage your fault or not. Don't bother reporting people for breaking rules if that store seems desperate to keep employees because all you will do is create enemies. If you are interested in becoming a manager one day keep it a secret or your manager will secretly try to run you off.

main_text: I have been working at Payless ShoeSource full-time for more than 5 years
pros: I love working here. Everything has its ups and downs. If you learn from past situations evolve for the better then this is a career. If you decide to complain and do not offer a resolution to the problem its a job. I have chosen to realize it's not my company but I have chosen to represent it. If I have a problem I talk to the appropriate person to resolve it. If I wrote my own checks things might be different. The point is look inward, do you talk negative of the company to other Associates? Do you reflect personal problems to others at work. Then sorry to say your the problem. Not sure if it's a mentality thing or a self discovery with age. I have seen it both ways. I think complaining about any Company is worthless unless it's yours or you take the proper steps to talk to the proper people with your opinion of a new idea. A complaint solves nothing it just creates negative vibes. Bring something to the table and keep spirits up. It changes things for the best.
